ECR criticizes the prioritization of non-safety issues like "made in" labeling requirements over core market surveillance improvements, undermining single market efficiency.  
ECR condemns the proposal's disregard for proportionality, emphasizing zero consumer complaints about products targeted by the food-resemblance ban.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading, adopting it based on Articles 33, 114, and 207 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0075), which aimed to harmonize internal market rules and trade policies. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and the Committee on International Trade, as outlined in report A7-0346/2013, and considered the European Economic and Social Committee’s May 2013 opinion. It urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if intending substantial amendments and directed the Parliament’s President to transmit the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legal frameworks and procedural accountability.

title: Internal Market Scoreboard: REPORT on the Internal Market Scoreboard
background: The European Commission monitors Member States' transposition of internal market directives, with persistent transposition delays and market fragmentation affecting cross-border economic activities. The Parliament will discuss measures to enhance the internal market's functionality through improved legislative implementation and enforcement mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the enhancement of SOLVIT resources and visibility, aligning with their commitment to efficient single market governance, while proposing increased staffing and integration with EU advisory services to address transposition delays.  
EPP approves the annual Internal Market Forum proposal, emphasizing its critical role in institutionalizing best practice exchange and reinforcing enforcement collaboration between Member States.  
EPP endorses the "internal-market test" mechanism to ensure legislative coherence, highlighting its necessity to balance consumer protections with enterprise competitiveness per EPP's market stability priorities.  
EPP advocates consolidating market information portals into a unified 'Your Europe - Business' hub, aligning with SME support goals while suggesting accelerated Small Business Act transposition to maximize market potential.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous SOLVIT promotion campaigns across Member States, framing enhanced citizen awareness as pivotal to realizing the issue's full impact on cross-border dispute issue efficiency.

EFD conditionally promotes the Consumer Markets Scoreboard but demands exemptions for micro-enterprises to prevent regulatory overreach akin to destructive fisheries policy impacts.  
EFD rejects the harmonization of surveillance structures as inconsistent with national sovereignty principles, citing unresolved tensions from immigration and labor market interventions.  
The proposal completely condemns with EFD's stance against bureaucratic expansion by creating overlapping enforcement mechanisms that burden small retailers.  
EFD requests deletion of long-term consumer indicators, arguing they perpetuate self-referential regulation divorced from local market realities.  
This overlooks critical SME concerns by expanding SOLVIT without binding commitments to reduce compliance costs for cross-border traders.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue's narrow internal-market check as absolutely disapproveing with their principles, arguing it prioritizes market functionality over mandatory sustainability and social impact assessments.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the fragmented commissioner responsibilities for consumer protection, stating this structure overlooks critical aspects of maintaining unified, high-level safeguards essential for public trust.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's failure to mandate comprehensive legislative reviews encompassing environmental and social dimensions, inconsistent with their demand for holistic policy evaluations.  
GREEN_EFA criticizes the insufficient integration of subsidiarity principles in market governance, contradicting their advocacy for decentralized decision-making aligned with regional socioecological priorities.  
GREEN_EFA conditionally acknowledges SOLVIT's role but stresses the issue's neglect of parallel collective redress mechanisms fails to address systemic consumer justice gaps undermining market confidence.

ALDE fully supports the issue’s emphasis on strengthening SOLVIT centers, perfectly aligning with their longstanding commitment to reducing bureaucratic barriers for SMEs through rapid, pragmatic dispute issue.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for an “internal-market test” to safeguard legislative integrity, reflecting their manifesto priority of preventing fragmented market rules that disadvantage cross-border enterprises.  
ALDE fully supports the annual Internal Market Forum proposal, recognizing it as essential to advancing their goal of systematic best-practice sharing between Member States and EU institutions.  
ALDE strongly approves consolidating market information into the ‘Your Europe – Business’ portal, a measure that directly advances their advocacy for streamlined SME access to cross-border opportunities.  
ALDE fully supports the issue’s focus on consumer education and collective redress mechanisms, highlighting the critical need for a European model of class action to reinforce trust in cross-border transactions.

SD strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on collaborative governance and early transposition dialogue, aligning perfectly with their commitment to harmonizing market efficiency with robust social protections.  

SD approves the expansion of SOLVIT resources and visibility campaigns, proposing binding minimum staffing levels across all Member States to address critical capacity gaps highlighted in national cases.  

SD recommends enhancing the proposed "internal-market test" to explicitly evaluate impacts on worker rights and consumer safeguards, ensuring market functionality complements rather than compromises social standards.  

SD endorses consolidating market tools into the 'Your Europe - Business' portal, urging future integration of sustainability performance metrics to reflect evolving responsible consumption patterns.  

SD applauds mandatory civil servant training provisions, suggesting supplemental modules on environmental market regulations to accelerate green transition synergies.

GUE_NGL rejects the issue's reliance on unregulated competition as a driver of prosperity, entirely challengeing with their principle that market mechanisms fail to protect vulnerable consumers without price controls on essential goods.  
GUE_NGL opposes the Internal Market Scoreboard's numerical performance metrics, which overlook critical aspects like quantifiable social targets and wealth redistribution to address systemic inequality.  
GUE_NGL condemns the "internal-market test" proposal as inherently prioritizing corporate interests over public welfare, inconsistent with their demand for legislation centered on human needs rather than market integrity.  
GUE_NGL challenges the assumption that administrative burden reduction benefits citizens, arguing it weakens safeguards against corporate profiteering and deregulation of worker protections.  
GUE_NGL dismisses the issue’s consumer confidence framework as inadequate, emphasizing that true security requires binding price caps and anti-speculation measures absent from the text.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need for Member States to fully implement all measures under the Commission’s 2009 Recommendation to improve the single market, avoiding selective adoption. It urged closer collaboration between Member States, the Commission, and stakeholders to enforce internal market rules effectively, reduce administrative burdens, and address transposition deficits through early dialogue, information exchange, and support during transposition. The resolution emphasized involving national parliaments, social partners, and regional authorities in legislative processes to ensure correct transposition and implementation, critical for market functionality, competition, and stability. It called for an annual Internal Market Forum (with working and ministerial-level meetings) to share best practices and strengthen commitment to enforcement. The Parliament stressed enhancing the Internal Market Scoreboard with detailed enforcement data, objective indicators, and synchronized annual publication alongside SOLVIT, Consumer Market Scoreboard, and Citizens Signpost reports to provide a comprehensive market overview. It advocated for an "internal-market test" to prevent new legislation from undermining market integrity, improved legislative quality via impact assessments, and ex-post evaluations to assess effectiveness. Member States were urged to provide detailed transposition data via correlation tables, boost SOLVIT resources for dispute resolution, and increase visibility of its services. The resolution highlighted consolidating fragmented market information into the 'Your Europe - Business' portal as a one-stop-shop, leveraging the Enterprise Europe Network to support SMEs while reducing bureaucratic hurdles, and ensuring regular training for civil servants on internal market rules.

title: Internal market scoreboard: REPORT on the Internal Market Scoreboard
background: Persistent transposition delays and compliance deficits in EU Member States, alongside fragmented application of single market rules, prompted regular monitoring through Commission scoreboards and tools like SOLVIT. The Parliament will discuss improving governance mechanisms to address gaps in timely implementation of internal market legislation and enhance cross-border problem resolution for citizens and businesses.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's transparency measures for infringement proceedings, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to open governance and uniform application of single market rules.  
EPP entirely sanctions reinforcing SOLVIT's operational efficiency while proposing enhanced legal clarity to avoid subsidiarity conflicts, ensuring swift dispute issue remains accessible.  
EPP approves mandating correlation tables across all Member States as a critical tool to monitor legislative transposition quality, building on Malta's exemplary implementation model.  
EPP applauds leveraging Lisbon Treaty Article 260(3) to impose fines for non-compliance, effectively advancing EPP's priority of enforceable market integration amid economic challenges.  
EPP emphasizes expanding coordinated communication portals like Your Europe to address fragmentation, ensuring SMEs fully utilize single market opportunities.

EFD partially upholds the issue’s focus on transposition mechanisms but entirely disputes with its inadequate attention to product safety oversight, a core EFD consumer protection priority.  
EFD requests revisions to strengthen certification body mandates, citing recurring market scandals like contaminated French poultry and repackaged road salt as evidence of systemic gaps.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as harmonized food quality controls, which Paška’s examples show enable hazardous products to undermine single market integrity.  
EFD demands amendments to Section 4 on redress mechanisms to include stricter penalties for negligent certification authorities and real-time product recall protocols.  
This aligns partially with EFD’s emphasis on national sovereignty in market regulation but fails to address fragmented enforcement enabling low-quality goods, contrary to their consumer-first principles.

ALDE totally agrees the issue’s emphasis on strict enforcement of timely directive transposition, perfectly aligning with their commitment to eliminating internal market fragmentation and ensuring equal competitive conditions.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with leveraging Article 260(3) of the Lisbon Treaty to impose fines for non-compliance, reflecting their unwavering stance on binding accountability mechanisms to uphold EU law integrity.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s recognition of Malta’s exemplary transposition record and Estonia’s compliance, reinforcing ALDE’s prioritization of benchmarking excellence to drive peer accountability among Member States.  
ALDE totally agrees enhancing SOLVIT’s visibility and resources, viewing it as essential to fulfilling their manifesto goal of streamlining cross-border dispute issue and empowering citizens within the single market.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the call for regular Single Market Forums, mirroring their advocacy for structured dialogue to dismantle regulatory obstacles and sustain the internal market’s role as Europe’s growth engine.

SD strongly promotes the issue’s emphasis on timely transposition and effective redress mechanisms, aligning with their commitment to a functional internal market that benefits citizens and SMEs.  
SD applauds the focus on SOLVIT’s enhancement, urging increased resources and visibility to better address market fragmentation, while proposing a formal legal basis to maximize its potential.  
SD welcomes the call for improved coordination between EU assistance services, emphasizing the need to prioritize social cohesion and worker protections in future governance check-ups.  
SD suggests reconsidering the late proposal for a Single Market Prosecutor, advocating instead for strengthening existing infringement procedures and Court of Justice efficiency.  
SD highlights the importance of addressing crisis-driven non-compliance through targeted support and incentives, ensuring Member States’ challenges are met with solidarity alongside enforcement.

ECR strongly endorses enhanced enforcement through transparent infringement reporting and "name and shame" mechanisms, aligning with their prioritization of single market accountability.  
ECR applauds the focus on digital single market completion through high-speed internet investment and cross-border payment reforms as critical growth drivers.  
ECR approves leveraging Article 260(3) for faster infringement penalties but proposes integrating Eurobarometer data on SOLVIT awareness into governance reviews to quantify implementation gaps.  
ECR endorses establishing the Single Market Act as a dynamic program requiring continual updates to address emerging barriers, particularly in services and goods sectors.  
ECR emphasizes urgent Member State action to streamline transposition processes while advocating strengthened "Your Europe" branding for unified citizen access to rights.

GUE/NGL partly agrees the issue's governance check-up but demands amendments to prioritize public investment over market liberalization, inconsistent with their anti-austerity principles.  
GUE/NGL requests revisions to paragraph 33, explicitly linking "sustainable growth" to green public sector job creation and workers' rights protections rather than corporate interests.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue's omission of external market barriers contributing to Mediterranean migrant fatalities, urging binding provisions to address humanitarian consequences of trade policies.  
GUE/NGL totally againsts with the issue's tacit endorsement of privatization policies, citing Portugal's SME collapse and energy sector sell-offs as critical oversights requiring reversal clauses.  
GUE/NGL partly agrees infringement procedures but insists Article 260(3) fines be reallocated to social equity programs in affected member states rather than EU coffers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns over persistent delays and deficiencies in Member States’ transposition and implementation of EU internal market legislation, noting the average transposition deficit of 1.2% exceeded the 1% target, with 85 directives remaining untransposed in at least one Member State and two directives over two years overdue. It highlighted Malta’s exemplary transposition record, Belgium’s poor performance, and Estonia’s strong compliance across indicators. The resolution stressed the critical role of the Internal Market Scoreboard in monitoring compliance and welcomed the Commission’s Annual Governance Check-up for consolidating tools like SOLVIT, which resolves misapplication cases within 10 weeks on average, though urged enhanced resources, training, and visibility for SOLVIT to address fragmentation and underuse. Parliament called for stricter enforcement of infringement procedures, particularly in taxation and environment sectors (constituting nearly 50% of cases), and urged Member States to improve transposition quality through correlation tables and reduce delays. It emphasized the need for better coordination between EU assistance services (e.g., Your Europe, Points of Single Contact) to streamline citizen and business access to rights, advocated for regular Single Market Forums to address obstacles, and pushed for improved public awareness of single market benefits. The resolution also urged leveraging the Lisbon Treaty’s Article 260(3) to impose fines for non-compliance and demanded Commission evaluations of disability-related market barriers and petitions’ impact on legislation. Overall, it framed timely, accurate transposition and effective redress mechanisms as vital to unlocking growth and competitiveness amid economic challenges.

title: Governance of the single market: REPORT with recommendations to the Commission on the governance of the Single Market
background: Persistent transposition deficits and incomplete implementation of Single Market rules by EU member states, alongside rising regulatory fragmentation, hindered economic integration and growth, undermining the Europe 2020 Strategy’s objectives. The Parliament will discuss strengthening governance mechanisms to enhance the Single Market’s effectiveness in fostering competitiveness, job creation, and social cohesion.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the issue's emphasis on fiscal consolidation and structural reforms as essential foundations for restoring investor confidence and sustainable growth within the Single Market framework.  
EPP approves the prioritization of SME-friendly legislation and administrative burden reduction, aligning with their manifesto commitment to competitiveness while proposing enhanced one-stop shop mechanisms for cross-border business registration.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous enforcement of existing Single Market rules over new regulations, advocating for stricter monitoring of member state transposition deficits through the European Semester process.  
EPP highlights the need to balance social cohesion objectives with fiscal responsibility, suggesting clearer guidelines to prevent welfare systems from disincentivizing labor market participation.  
EPP applauds the integration of Single Market governance with digital completion goals, particularly initiatives to harmonize e-commerce standards while maintaining consumer protection safeguards.

EFD rejects the issue's emphasis on enhanced Single Market governance as fundamentally contradicting their belief that EU overregulation stifles economic growth.  
EFD opposes the legislative framework under Article 26(3) TFEU, arguing it would exacerbate bureaucratic burdens on businesses, as seen in Godfrey Bloom’s critique of “overtaxed, overregulated” policies.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects such as national sovereignty in labor laws, exemplified by Derek Clark’s defense of the UK’s Working Time Directive opt-out to reduce unemployment.  
EFD condemns the issue’s alignment with the European Semester as a “suicidal” centralization effort, echoing Morten Messerschmidt’s condemnation of EU strategies that “short-circuit democracies.”  
This entirely condemns with EFD’s position that austerity and EU fiscal consolidation deepen crises, as Claudio Morganti highlighted with Italy’s unemployment-driven tragedies.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the issue's integration of social and environmental priorities into Single Market governance, aligning perfectly with their commitment to balancing economic growth with social equity and sustainability.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the emphasis on SME regulatory relief while proposing enhanced safeguards for health/safety standards to prevent unintended erosion of worker protections.  
GREEN_EFA endorses linking Single Market governance to the European Semester as a strategic tool to address macroeconomic imbalances, mirroring their call for coordinated investment in sustainable infrastructure.  
GREEN_EFA approves the focus on labor mobility and professional qualification recognition but urges explicit inclusion of wage convergence mechanisms to combat social dumping risks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the issue's alignment with their digital accessibility demands, particularly its reference to UN disability rights, as critical for achieving an inclusive Single Market.

ALDE strongly agrees the issue's emphasis on completing the Single Market through harmonized legislation and reduced administrative burdens for SMEs, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to competitive entrepreneurship.  
ALDE approves the call for smarter IT tools and digital market integration as critical enhancements to cross-border business operations and citizen empowerment.  
ALDE proposes strengthening communication strategies to better demonstrate the Single Market's value to SMEs, noting current awareness gaps despite existing EU outreach efforts.  
ALDE applauds the linkage between governance reforms and fiscal discipline, echoing their insistence on structural reforms in labor markets and pension systems for sustainable recovery.  
ALDE emphasizes strict enforcement of transposition deadlines to rebuild EU credibility, aligning with their issue-backed demand for Article 26(3) TFEU governance frameworks.

SD strongly promotes the integration of Single Market governance with social cohesion priorities, aligning with the issue's emphasis on preventing social dumping through coordinated fiscal convergence.  
SD approves the call for differentiated deficit reduction timelines to account for fiscal multipliers, proposing enhanced flexibility in austerity implementation as a growth-enhancing modification to Article 26(3) TFEU frameworks.  
SD endorses the youth guarantee provisions and digital market completion as critical for job creation, directly advancing the issue's employment goals through accessible skills development programs.  
SD emphasizes the need to harmonize corporate tax policies and combat tax havens, strengthening the issue's governance framework with concrete anti-evasion mechanisms beyond current proposals.  
SD highlights the necessity of maintaining collective bargaining rights in competitiveness strategies, ensuring the issue's social dimension prevents wage suppression while achieving market integration.

GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s alignment with austerity-driven governance frameworks like the European Semester, which prioritize fiscal consolidation over public investment and social protection.  
GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the emphasis on labor market flexibility and temporary contracts, which institutionalize precarious work and erode pension sustainability.  
GUE/NGL condemns the failure to address how austerity measures—embedded in Single Market fiscal convergence—directly fuel unemployment and poverty, contradicting stated social cohesion goals.  
GUE/NGL challenges the issue’s reliance on private sector-led growth, noting corporate profit hoarding and disinvestment as root causes of economic stagnation.  
GUE/NGL demands rejection of debt repayment frameworks that transfer banking crisis costs to workers, advocating instead for radical public investment in jobs and services.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the urgent need to complete and strengthen the Single Market to boost growth, competitiveness, and job creation, emphasizing its role as the backbone of the EU’s economic recovery and the Europe 2020 Strategy. Despite 20 years of existence, the Single Market remains incomplete due to Member States’ failure to fully transpose approximately 1,500 directives and 1,000 regulations, with transposition deficits rising from 0.7% in 2009 to 1.2% in 2012 before improving to 0.9%, undermining trust in the EU. The resolution called for enhanced governance, including a legislative framework under Article 26(3) TFEU, to improve transposition, implementation, and enforcement of rules, balancing economic, social, and environmental priorities while integrating consumer protection, social rights, and sustainability. It stressed the importance of reducing regulatory burdens for SMEs and micro-enterprises through tailored legislation, while safeguarding health and safety standards, and advocated for one-stop shops, digital market completion, and accessible services for persons with disabilities. The Parliament highlighted fragmented services markets, low labor mobility, and administrative barriers, urging simplified recognition of professional qualifications and smarter IT tools to empower citizens and businesses. Social cohesion, fiscal convergence, and prevention of social dumping were emphasized, alongside calls for consistent enforcement of EU directives, strengthened cross-border cooperation, and alignment of national action plans with EU guidelines to foster growth, employment, and a level playing field. The resolution also linked Single Market governance to the European Semester, advocating for a coherent framework to address market deficiencies, support regional growth, and integrate accessibility under the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities.

title: Repeal of directives regarding metrology: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Directives 71//317/EEC, 71/347/EEC, 71/349/EEC, 74/148/EEC, 75/33/EEC, 76/765/EEC, 76/766/EEC, and 86/217/EEC regarding metrology
background: Eight EU metrology directives regulating specific measuring instruments became obsolete due to international standards and technological advancements, creating redundant regulations amid broader EU efforts to reduce administrative burdens. The Parliament will discuss repealing these directives as part of regulatory simplification in metrology to eliminate redundant legislation.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly accepts the repeal of outdated metrology directives as a critical step toward harmonizing technical standards across the EU.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on legal clarity, ensuring Member States retain sufficient transitional time to prevent regulatory uncertainty.  
EPP applauds the modernization of calibration frameworks to reflect current technological advancements and global trade requirements.  
EPP underscores the necessity of maintaining rigorous standardization practices while eliminating redundant legislation to bolster cross-border trade efficiency.  
EPP highlights the issue’s alignment with longstanding commitments to consumer protection through consistent measurement accuracy and regulatory simplification.

EFD supports the repeal of outdated metrology directives to modernize technical standards and reduce regulatory redundancies, aligning with efforts to ease burdens on businesses.  
EFD advises expediting the European Commission's proposal for a new Measuring Instruments Directive to ensure seamless regulatory transition and legal clarity.  
EFD highlights the capability of European businesses to utilize international standards and trade organizations to maintain market stability during the interim period.  
EFD emphasizes the importance of minimizing bureaucratic constraints and tax pressures on businesses to foster a dynamic and balanced European market.  
EFD acknowledges the issue's alignment with streamlining metrology frameworks but urges proactive legislative action to prevent future regulatory gaps.

GREEN_EFA entirely advocates the directive repeal as perfectly aligning with their commitment to modernized EU-wide metrology standards and elimination of regulatory redundancies.  
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the correlation table compromise, viewing it as essential for monitoring Member State compliance while anticipating stricter enforcement mechanisms in future MID revisions.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the issue effectively advances their priority of technological harmonization through updated calibration practices for trade and environmental measurement accuracy.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the critical need for ongoing Commission scrutiny of measurement frameworks to maintain alignment with evolving sustainability and consumer protection goals.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the preservation of core standardization objectives as foundational to their vision of transparent, science-based EU market regulations.

ALDE absolutely endorses the repeal of outdated metrology directives as a critical step toward harmonizing technical standards and eliminating regulatory redundancies, perfectly aligning with ALDE's commitment to streamlining EU legislation.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s emphasis on leveraging the mutual recognition principle to ensure free movement of goods, which advances ALDE's priority of fostering cross-border trade through regulatory efficiency.  
ALDE strongly agrees the integration of repealed directives’ provisions into the Measurements Instruments Directive, ensuring legal clarity and continuity while upholding consumer protection and measurement accuracy.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of preemptively addressing potential legal gaps through the Commission’s evaluation mechanism, reflecting ALDE's proactive stance on adaptive governance and technical coherence.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with modernized calibration practices as essential for maintaining global competitiveness, consistent with ALDE's advocacy for innovation-driven regulatory frameworks.

SD strongly sanctions the modernization of metrology frameworks through the repeal of outdated directives, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to regulatory efficiency and consumer protection in cross-border trade.  
SD approves the Commission’s assurance to examine integrating repealed instruments like alcohol meters and tyre pressure gauges into the Measuring Instruments Directive, proposing this as a critical enhancement opportunity to maintain standardization rigor.  
SD emphasizes the importance of robust correlation tables for legal clarity in future legislation, accepting the current compromise wording while advocating for stricter implementation checks to ensure harmonized enforcement across Member States.  
SD highlights the issue’s alignment with technological advancements in measurement accuracy, effectively advancing SD’s priority of eliminating redundancies while preserving core calibration standards.  
SD acknowledges the conditional nature of its support, urging swift Commission action to address unresolved technical details without opposing the repeal’s overarching objectives.

ECR strongly approves the repeal of outdated metrology directives as a critical step toward regulatory simplification and alignment with better regulation principles.  
ECR applauds the issue’s partial retention of deregulatory intent, aligning with their commitment to reducing EU overreach while preserving essential standardization frameworks.  
ECR proposes future reliance on international standards and mutual recognition over centralized harmonization to enhance flexibility in technical regulations.  
ECR emphasizes the need for rigorous impact assessments and early Member State consultation to strengthen future deregulation initiatives.  
ECR acknowledges the compromise solution as a qualified success but urges bolder alignment with liberalization goals in subsequent legislative updates.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the harmonization of technical standards across several EU directives, specifically addressing metrology and measurement instruments. The resolution highlighted the need to update or repeal outdated directives, including Directive 75/33/EEC on Cold Water Meters for Non-Clean Water, Directives 76/765/EEC and 76/766/EEC governing Alcohol Meters and Alcohol Tables, Directives 71/317/EEC and 74/148/EEC on Medium and Above-Medium Accuracy Weights, Directive 86/217/EEC on Tyre Pressure Gauges for Motor Vehicles, Directive 71/347/EEC on Standard Mass of Grain, and Directive 71/349/EEC on Calibration of Ship Tanks. It emphasized modernizing these frameworks to align with current technological and regulatory requirements, ensuring consistency in measurement accuracy, consumer protection, and cross-border trade. The resolution underscored the importance of maintaining legal clarity and eliminating redundancies while preserving the directives’ core objectives related to standardization and calibration practices.

title: Report: Catherine Trautmann - Electronic communication networks and services, 3rd reading on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee: REPORT on the joint text approved by the Conciliation Committee for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directives 2002/21/EC on a common regulatory framework for electronic communications networks and services, 2002/19/EC on access to, and interconnection of, electronic communications networks and associated facilities, and 2002/20/EC on the authorisation of electronic communications networks and services
background: The 2002 EU regulatory framework for electronic communications became outdated due to technological advances in high-speed internet, mobile services, and spectrum management, alongside evolving market competition and consumer protection needs in a digitalizing economy. The Parliament will discuss reforms to harmonize rules on network access, market authorization, and cross-border service coordination.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the finalized regulatory framework as effectively advancing its priorities for consumer rights protection and digital market competitiveness, aligning with EPP's commitment to innovation-driven economic growth.  
EPP applauds the balanced approach ensuring judicial oversight for internet access restrictions, which reinforces fundamental freedoms while maintaining Member States' legal autonomy in procedural matters.  
EPP approves the issue's safeguards for network neutrality and spectrum flexibility, noting these provisions will enhance Europe's global leadership in next-generation broadband infrastructure.  
EPP commends the focus on digital dividend utilization as critical for achieving EU technological sovereignty, directly supporting its 2023 agenda for harmonized spectrum management.  
EPP proposes future measures to strengthen intellectual property protections within electronic communications, ensuring alignment with evolving digital content markets.

EFD partly accepts the conciliation outcome but demands explicit judicial review requirements to prevent unchecked state surveillance powers  
EFD entirely doubts provisions exempting bureaucratic actions from court oversight, citing violations of Amendment 138's original intent  
EFD requests deletion of Article 1(3c) allowing commercial data exploitation without opt-in consent mechanisms  
EFD requires amendment to Section 4 to mandate real-time user notifications of all surveillance activities

ALDE strongly endorses the issue’s procedural safeguards for internet access, aligning with their commitment to judicial oversight as a cornerstone of digital rights protection.  
ALDE approves the conciliation committee’s improvements to legal clarity and user protections, effectively advancing regulatory coherence while respecting member states’ jurisdictional balance.  
ALDE proposes addressing the ‘three strikes’ mechanism through dedicated copyright legislation to avoid policy fragmentation, enhancing focus on telecommunications market modernization.  
ALDE acknowledges the issue as a foundational step toward net neutrality and urges future initiatives to harmonize open access to knowledge with intellectual property safeguards.  
ALDE commends the inclusion of judicial review prerequisites for restricting user rights, viewing this as critical for upholding EU freedoms in digital governance frameworks.

SD strongly agrees the issue’s consumer protection framework, particularly emergency service access and disability accommodations, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to equitable digital inclusion.  
SD applauds the safeguards for net neutrality and anti-competitive practice prohibitions, which effectively advance SD’s priority of fair market conditions in telecommunications.  
SD proposes amending Article 9 to mandate real-person customer service channels for telecom providers, addressing consumer frustrations with automated systems while preserving issue efficiency goals.  
SD highlights the issue’s data breach notification requirements as critical progress, urging explicit disclosure rules for third-party data usage in software downloads to strengthen transparency.  
SD commends the negotiated compromise on user sanctions and billing clarity, recognizing these as vital steps toward balancing corporate accountability with consumer rights.

ECR strongly sanctions the finalized legislative package, particularly its robust consumer rights protections and net neutrality safeguards, which align with their commitment to market transparency and user empowerment.  
ECR applauds the strengthened provisions on data breach notification and cookie consent requirements as critical advancements in digital consumer protection.  
ECR welcomes the Commission’s declaration on net neutrality enforcement, reflecting their longstanding advocacy for open internet principles.  
ECR proposes enhancing clarity in implementing the data breach framework to prevent divergent interpretations by member states, while fully endorsing the agreed text.  
ECR emphasizes the urgency of swift Commission action to operationalize the directive’s consumer-centric measures across all EU markets.

GUE_NGL totally againsts the issue’s failure to mandate judicial review for user restrictions, enabling arbitrary measures by authorities and ISPs under Article 1(3a).  
GUE_NGL rejects the exclusion of binding net neutrality guarantees, which permits commercial agreements to fragment internet access into restricted channels (Amendment 138).  
GUE_NGL condemns the subordination of freedom of expression to internal market rules, as Article 2(7) grants the European Court of Justice authority over civil liberties.  
GUE_NGL opposes the prioritization of corporate interests over user rights, allowing service providers to impose restrictions via contractual terms (Annex IV).  
GUE_NGL declares the procedural framework incompatible with democratic principles, as it institutionalizes surveillance risks under Recital 22.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the joint text negotiated through the conciliation process, which reconciled differing positions on the Commission’s amended proposal (COM(2008)0724) and the Council’s common position. It formally adopted the finalized legislative act, instructing its President to sign it jointly with the Council’s President under Article 254(1) of the EC Treaty, thereby finalizing the legislative procedure. The Parliament further directed its Secretary-General to verify procedural compliance, coordinate with the Council’s Secretary-General to publish the act alongside the Commission’s explanatory statement in the Official Journal of the EU, and ensure transparency. Additionally, it mandated its President to transmit the resolution to the Council and Commission, concluding the legislative process initiated under the Commission’s original proposal (COM(2007)0697) and subsequent amendments.

title: Protection of consumers in utilities services: REPORT on consumer protection – protection of consumers in utilities services
background: The European Union has established sector-specific consumer protection frameworks for energy, telecommunications, postal services, and public transport, with directives requiring national implementation. Persistent challenges in market transparency, service accessibility, and vulnerable consumer inclusion across member states preceded parliamentary consideration. The Parliament will discuss strengthening consumer safeguards in essential utilities services under existing EU legislation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's focus on transparent energy pricing and smart metering systems, which aligns perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to consumer empowerment through market efficiency and data protection.  
EPP approves the emphasis on sector-specific regulations for telecommunications and postal services, recognizing this as essential for maintaining national competences while advancing EU-wide interoperability.  
EPP endorses the call for robust market surveillance mechanisms, particularly the proposed pan-European accident database, to strengthen product safety in line with EPP's 2023 competitiveness agenda.  
EPP proposes refining the "made in" labeling criteria in Article 7 to clarify thresholds for "last substantial transformation," ensuring SMEs can comply without disproportionate burdens.  
EPP applauds the issue’s balanced approach to vulnerable consumers’ needs, mirroring their manifesto pledge to integrate social equity into single market policies.

EFD supports the issue’s consumer transparency goals but advises mandating "origin disclosure" for utility services, such as energy generation sources or telecom infrastructure providers, to mirror product labeling demands raised by Salvini.  
EFD advocates amending consumer information clauses to require explicit data on multinational corporate ties in utility sectors, countering profit-driven practices criticized in the debate.  
EFD endorses simplified provider switching but proposes a 7-day maximum transition period for energy/telecom services, avoiding bureaucratic delays akin to Morganti’s call for streamlined processes.  
EFD highlights the need to prioritize local utility providers in public contracts, aligning with their emphasis on protecting European workers against external competition.  
EFD advises expanding vulnerable consumer protections to include subsidies for locally sourced utilities, ensuring affordability while reinforcing sustainability goals.

GREEN_EFA rejects the issue’s failure to break Council deadlocks on market surveillance reforms, perpetuating weak cross-border consumer protections.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the flawed origin labeling provisions that mislead consumers instead of enabling genuine product traceability, contradicting transparency pledges.  
GREEN_EFA absolutely challenges with any dilution of "made in" requirements, which are indispensable for ecological relocalization and consumer empowerment.  
GREEN_EFA criticizes the prioritization of bureaucratic processes over actionable mechanisms to strengthen consumer rights enforcement.  
GREEN_EFA demands binding traceability standards rather than superficial labeling, aligning with their vision for sustainable supply chains.

ALDE strongly sanctions the issue's emphasis on reducing bureaucratic burdens for SMEs, proposing to amend Article 7 by replacing mandatory "EU safety tested" markings with risk-based testing protocols to maintain product safety without unnecessary compliance costs.  
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s market surveillance improvements, aligning with ALDE's priority of streamlined procedures that enhance consumer protection while maintaining free movement of goods.  
ALDE strongly sanctions maintaining "Made in" as a voluntary quality indicator rather than a safety requirement, proposing to preserve it as a trademark system separate from product safety regulations.  
ALDE strongly sanctions combating protectionism through smarter labeling rules, advocating for origin disclosure only where materially relevant to safety to avoid trade distortions.  
ALDE strongly sanctions the issue’s digital single market goals, urging faster implementation of ODR systems to match ALDE’s 2023 manifesto commitments on consumer redress.

SD strongly sanctions enhanced product safety measures, particularly mandatory origin labeling and traceability systems, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to protecting vulnerable consumers like children and the elderly.  
SD approves the issue's focus on energy transparency but proposes reinstating explicit provisions on energy poverty to address rising costs impacting low-income households.  
SD endorses pan-European injury databases and unified safety standards as critical tools to eliminate hazardous products, effectively advancing SD's priority of evidence-based consumer protection.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of strict enforcement mechanisms for market surveillance, including penalties for non-compliance, to ensure a level playing field for ethical businesses.  
SD applauds the precautionary principle integration in utility regulations, urging swift implementation of smart metering systems with robust data protection safeguards.

ECR fully promotes the issue's emphasis on balanced regulation that protects consumers without imposing disproportionate burdens on businesses, perfectly aligning with their commitment to market efficiency.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's call for rigorous implementation of existing directives on energy security and vulnerable consumer protections, as highlighted in Croatia's need for enforcement frameworks.  
ECR fully promotes the prioritization of transparent pricing and simplified provider switching in telecom/energy markets, mirroring their focus on consumer empowerment through competitive choices.  
ECR perfectly aligns with the issue's smart metering provisions that respect data protection, reinforcing their stance on innovation paired with individual privacy safeguards.  
ECR fully promotes the rejection of excessive product bans that stifle innovation, proposing enhanced risk assessments instead of blanket prohibitions on non-food items resembling foodstuffs.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the need to strengthen consumer rights and ensure access to affordable, high-quality utility services across the EU, emphasizing energy, telecommunications, postal services, and public transport. It stressed the importance of fully implementing existing directives, including the Consumer Rights Directive (2011/83/EU) by June 2014, the Unfair Commercial Practices Directive (2005/29/EC), and measures to enforce consumer rights through alternative dispute resolution (ADR) and online dispute resolution (ODR) systems. The resolution highlighted the necessity of transparent pricing, simplified switching of energy and telecom providers, and enhanced consumer information campaigns, particularly for vulnerable consumers, who may require tailored support. In energy, it called for timely implementation of the third internal energy market package to achieve competitive prices, security of supply, and sustainability, alongside smart metering systems that respect consumer choice and data protection. For telecommunications, it advocated easier provider switching without fees, improved service transparency, and bridging the digital divide. Postal services were urged to enhance delivery reliability, interoperability, and cost efficiency, while public transport policies should prioritize accessibility for the elderly and people with limited mobility, aligning with climate goals. The resolution also underscored the role of independent consumer organizations and balanced regulation to protect consumers without overburdening service providers.

title: Public procurement: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on public procurement
background: The EU's public procurement framework, governing 18% of GDP, faced calls for modernization to address legal fragmentation, inefficiencies, and evolving market needs. National parliaments raised subsidiarity concerns, while cross-border procurement complexities and post-2008 budgetary pressures highlighted gaps in existing directives. The Parliament will discuss harmonizing procurement rules to improve transparency, competition, and administrative flexibility.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the modernization of public procurement rules to prioritize quality and sustainability over lowest-price criteria, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to fostering innovation and long-term economic value.  
EPP approves the streamlined procedures enabling SME participation through divided contract lots, effectively advancing EPP's priority of empowering small businesses as growth engines.  
EPP endorses the integration of life-cycle costing and energy efficiency standards, which align with EPP's 2023 manifesto goals for green public investments and resource efficiency.  
EPP proposes ensuring member states implement transparency requirements without bureaucratic overreach to maintain the directive’s simplification intent.  
EPP applauds the issue’s emphasis on strategic procurement as a tool to meet Europe 2020 targets, particularly in driving technological progress and regional development.

EFD fundamentally disputes with the harmonization approach in Articles 53(1) and 114 TFEU, which undermines local business protections through excessive cross-border competition.  
EFD rejects the issue's failure to implement concrete "kilometro zero" thresholds that would prioritize regional enterprises amid Italy's 40% youth unemployment crisis.  
EFD opposes the absence of binding subcontracting limits in mutual recognition frameworks, creating loopholes exploited by criminal organizations through unregulated labor chains.  
EFD highlights the proposal's non-compliance with subsidiarity principles raised by national parliaments, particularly regarding port concessions and service sector disparities between Germany and Italy.  
EFD condemns the bureaucratic focus on "streamlined procedures" that ignores real-world administrative failures, as evidenced by Parliament's 18-month hemicycle repair procurement debacle.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the integration of environmental and social criteria in public procurement processes, aligning perfectly with their commitment to sustainability and fair trade practices.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on lifecycle costing over lowest-price bidding, which effectively advances innovation and market access for eco-friendly technologies.  
GREEN_EFA proposes reinforcing provisions for small businesses by mandating contract division into smaller lots and simplifying administrative requirements to reduce barriers to entry.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes the exclusion of water services from privatization frameworks, a critical safeguard for public ownership consistent with citizen-led initiatives like Right2Water.  
GREEN_EFA suggests further streamlining cross-border qualification assessments to minimize bureaucratic delays while maintaining rigorous transparency and labor-rights protections.

ALDE fundamentally upholds the modernization of EU procurement rules through this directive, perfectly aligning with its commitment to a competitive single market with reduced administrative barriers for SMEs.  
ALDE highlights the issue's success in preserving municipal cooperation models while preventing unfair public-private competition, effectively advancing regional economic cohesion.  
ALDE applauds the explicit exclusion of water services from privatization requirements and emergency rescue services from tendering rules, securing vital public service continuity as outlined in Article 9 revisions.  
ALDE emphasizes the issue's breakthrough in replacing lowest-cost bidding with economically advantageous criteria, a reform long championed in its market efficiency agendas.  
 While welcoming reduced upfront documentation for SMEs, ALDE proposes monitoring implementation to ensure national authorities fully adopt self-declaration mechanisms per Article 7(2).

SD absolutely agrees the exclusion of water services from the concessions directive, perfectly aligning with SD's commitment to safeguarding public control over essential services as demonstrated by the successful European Citizens' Initiative.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's shift from lowest-price criteria to economically most advantageous offers, advancing SD's priority of integrating social, environmental, and quality standards in public procurement.  
SD absolutely agrees the binding social clauses requiring compliance with collective bargaining agreements and environmental obligations throughout subcontracting chains, effectively advancing workers' rights across member states.  
SD perfectly supports the simplified electronic procurement procedures and SME access provisions, which align with SD's longstanding commitment to reducing administrative barriers for small businesses in EU markets.  
SD absolutely agrees the legal clarity maintaining public authorities' autonomy in organizing services of general economic interest, consistent with SD's principles of subsidiarity and territorial cohesion.

GUE_NGL partially accepts the social/environmental criteria in procurement but demands amendments to Article 15c requiring quality standards as binding minimum thresholds.  
GUE_NGL fully disputes concessions directive provisions enabling marketization of public services, contradicting their anti-privatization principles for essential resources like water.  
GUE_NGL requests mandatory parliamentary debate before trilogue negotiations, citing democratic erosion through procedural bypasses of legislative scrutiny.  
GUE_NGL highlights unresolved contradictions in prioritizing corporate competition over SME protections in public contracts, failing to address employment safeguards raised in João Ferreira's intervention.  
GUE_NGL requires strengthened cross-border enforcement mechanisms against tax-evading contractors, proposing explicit exclusion clauses for entities violating collective bargaining agreements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0896) aimed at harmonizing rules for the recognition of professional qualifications across EU member states, grounded in Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union Articles 53(1), 62, and 114. It acknowledged objections from the UK House of Commons and Swedish Parliament contesting compliance with subsidiarity principles, while incorporating opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urging the Commission to ensure mutual recognition frameworks balance labor mobility with public safety and consumer protection. It emphasized the need for streamlined administrative procedures, enhanced transparency in qualification assessments, and reinforced mechanisms for cross-border disciplinary information sharing. Parliament further called on the Commission to revisit the proposal through renewed parliamentary scrutiny if substantial revisions arise and directed its President to formally communicate the adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national legislatures.

title: Recognition of professional qualifications and administrative cooperation through the Internal Market Information System: REPORT proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2005/36/EC on the recognition of professional qualifications and Regulation on administrative cooperation through the Internal Market Information System
background: Persistent barriers to cross-border labor mobility within the EU single market, stemming from divergent national regulations on professional qualifications and administrative coordination inefficiencies, prompted legislative review. The Parliament will discuss updating the 2005 framework to harmonize recognition processes and strengthen cooperation mechanisms for regulated professions.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the introduction of the European Professional Card as a transformative tool to enhance worker mobility and align with the EU’s single market objectives, echoing Constance Le Grip’s emphasis on operationalizing citizenship rights.  
EPP applauds the streamlined recognition procedures for nurses and dual education systems, aligning with Andreas Schwab’s commitment to maintaining high training standards while addressing sector-specific labor shortages.  
EPP proposes reinforcing Article 7 to explicitly link qualification frameworks with national education reforms, addressing Milan Zver’s call for comparable learning outcomes to prevent recognition disparities.  
EPP emphasizes rigorous monitoring of unemployment data transparency to prevent member states from misrepresenting workforce outflows, reflecting Zdravka Bušić’s caution against statistical manipulation.  
EPP endorses automatic recognition mechanisms for pre-2004 nursing qualifications highlighted by Elżbieta Łukacijewska, ensuring equal access to labor markets for Polish healthcare professionals.

EFD fully disputes the proposal's erosion of national professional sovereignty, exemplified by risks to Italy's culturally vital tour guide sector.  
EFD rejects the issue's failure to prevent discriminatory qualification non-recognition, as demonstrated by the unjust treatment of UK ski instructors in France.  
EFD highlights the proposal's threat to cultural heritage preservation by enabling unqualified "pseudo-guides" through cross-border loopholes.  
EFD condemns the framework's inconsistency with subsidiarity principles, directly conflicting with protections for member states' unique professional landscapes.  
EFD asserts the text overlooks critical worker protections, enabling administrative harassment of qualified professionals under flawed mutual recognition mechanisms.

GREEN_EFA strongly advocates the issue’s alignment with EU freedoms, particularly worker mobility and cross-border service provision, while urging targeted improvements to language and education safeguards.  

GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 53 to explicitly authorize member states and regions to enforce context-specific language requirements for healthcare professionals, ensuring patient safety in multilingual areas like Brussels and linguistic rights in regions with co-official languages.  

GREEN_EFA highlights the need to preserve dual education systems such as Germany’s Meisterbrief, urging the Commission to clarify their protected status under the directive to prevent erosion of vocational training excellence.  

GREEN_EFA recommends revising Annex VII to require proof of regional language proficiency where necessary for professional practice, aligning with the EU’s commitment to linguistic diversity in nations like the Basque Country or Catalonia.  

GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on proportionality, urging strict adherence to subsidiarity in implementing language tests to avoid disproportionate barriers to labor mobility.

SD strongly advocates the introduction of the European Professional Card, which streamlines cross-border recognition of qualifications, aligning with S&D’s commitment to worker mobility and reduced administrative burdens.  
SD approves the mandatory alert mechanism for healthcare professionals, ensuring patient safety by preventing practitioners with revoked licenses from operating in other EU states, a critical safeguard for public health.  
SD emphasizes the need to harmonize training standards without compromising national excellence, particularly advocating for maintaining high-level nursing education to uphold both professional status and gender equality.  
SD endorses the modernization of minimum training requirements and inclusion of traineeships, advancing youth opportunities while balancing labor market needs with consumer protection priorities.  
SD highlights the importance of robust post-recognition language controls to ensure service quality, reinforcing trust in cross-border professional mobility while preserving linguistic accessibility.

ECR strongly sanctions the streamlined recognition procedures for professionals, particularly the inclusion of essential safety checks for health workers to ensure patient safety and communication standards.  
ECR applauds the establishment of an EU-wide alert mechanism as proposed in the issue, which aligns with their commitment to maintaining high professional standards while enabling mobility.  
ECR emphasizes the importance of the voluntary electronic professional card system to simplify verification processes, proposing enhanced interoperability between national databases for seamless implementation.  
ECR endorses the alignment of minimum training requirements across Member States, recognizing this as critical to eliminating discriminatory barriers and advancing single market principles.  
ECR highlights the need for consistent application of language competency assessments to build consumer trust, urging explicit guidelines in Annex VII to prevent divergent national interpretations.

GUE/NGL partly accepts the inclusion of language safeguards for healthcare professions but requests revisions to prevent uniform minimum standards from eroding national qualification systems.  
GUE/NGL totally opposes with the proposal’s market-driven approach, which prioritizes employer cost-cutting over worker protections and risks degrading service quality through lowered training benchmarks.  
GUE/NGL opposes the issue’s failure to address wage suppression mechanisms inherent in cross-border labor competition, inconsistent with their commitment to social equity.  
GUE/NGL demands amendments to Article 4 to explicitly prohibit member states from bypassing higher national qualification requirements, safeguarding against a “race to the bottom” in professional training.  
GUE/NGL rejects the framing of worker mobility as a tool for market efficiency, stressing the need to prioritize upward harmonization of labor rights over administrative convenience for employers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s legislative proposal (COM(2011)0883) on harmonizing national measures affecting the internal market, emphasizing compliance with Treaty provisions (Articles 46, 53(1), 62, and 114 TFEU). It noted objections from the French Senate under Protocol No 2, which argued the proposal breached subsidiarity, and referenced the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2012 opinion. Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to prioritize legal clarity, proportionality, and alignment with EU freedoms, particularly for workers and services. It insisted the Commission must resubmit the proposal to Parliament if making substantial amendments, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution also directed its President to transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring adherence to legislative procedures and interinstitutional accountability.

title: Textile names and related labelling of textile products: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on textile names and related labelling of textile products
background: Existing EU textile labeling rules, established through multiple directives, faced fragmentation due to varied national transpositions, complicating market access for innovative fibers and consumer clarity. The European Commission proposed replacing directives with a regulation to harmonize standards. The Parliament will discuss standardizing textile product labeling requirements to enhance internal market efficiency and consumer information transparency.

stances.stance:
EPP firmly agrees the mandatory origin labelling system for third-country textiles as a critical safeguard for consumer transparency and SME protection.  
EPP perfectly aligns with provisions accelerating market access for innovative fibres while maintaining strict EU safety standards for allergenic substance controls.  
EPP champions the "Made in Europe" optional label as a non-protectionist quality benchmark that reinforces worker rights and environmental compliance.  
EPP applauds the issue’s harmonisation of textile names across Article 114 TFEU as essential for reducing administrative burdens and boosting intra-EU competitiveness.  
EPP proposes strengthening digital traceability mechanisms in recital 18 to enhance supply chain visibility without delaying implementation timelines.

EFD slightly upholds the directive consolidation but requests removal of Amendment 58's EU-wide size labeling, which firmly disputes with national consumer sovereignty.  
EFD opposes harmonized sizing systems as inconsistent with the UK's established practices, viewing this as regulatory overreach under Lisbon Treaty implications.  
EFD supports allergen disclosure requirements yet demands explicit exemptions allowing member states to maintain existing size classification frameworks.  
EFD warns the issue overlooks critical subsidiarity principles by imposing centralized labeling standards instead of recognizing regional market diversity.  
EFD requests revisions to Article 4 to prohibit mandatory EU sizing codes, preserving language-independent symbols without supranational uniformity.

GREEN_EFA rejects the inclusion of origin marking provisions as incompatible with maintaining a functional textile labeling framework.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally condemns with attempts to expand the directive's scope, citing proven Council resistance risks that would delay novel fiber transparency measures.  
GREEN_EFA opposes merging origin labeling with material nomenclature, arguing this jeopardizes both objectives by reviving unresolved political deadlocks.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal's failure to address origin marking through dedicated legislative channels as required by their consumer protection principles.  
GREEN_EFA insists on separating novel fiber identification reforms from broader "Made in" debates to prevent procedural collapse.

ALDE strongly agrees the harmonization of textile labeling standards as a vital step toward EU market coherence and consumer transparency.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s alignment with free trade principles by addressing imbalances in global origin-marking practices, reflecting ALDE’s commitment to fair competition.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly require origin labeling for all textile products, ensuring parity with international trade partners like the U.S. and Japan.  
ALDE emphasizes the necessity of uniform labeling to eliminate manufacturer-driven inconsistencies, thereby advancing consumer protection as a core EU priority.  
ALDE endorses intercommittee coordination with the International Trade Committee to strengthen origin-tracing mechanisms without delaying market harmonization.

SD strongly accepts the harmonization of textile labelling rules under Article 114 TFEU, aligning with the party’s commitment to consumer transparency and internal market efficiency. The issue’s emphasis on 100% fibre composition lists directly advances SD priorities for empowering informed consumer choices.  

SD proposes enhancing origin labelling provisions by amending Article 4 to include “made in” disclosures, reinforcing ethical production standards and addressing concerns about child labor—a critical enhancement opportunity consistent with SD’s social justice principles.  

SD approves the mandate for future studies on comprehensive textile labelling, urging the Commission to integrate sizing standardization into this review to further boost cross-border trade, reflecting SD’s proactive stance on consumer-centric market integration.  

SD applauds the issue’s alignment with innovation-driven textile manufacturing, advocating for a subsequent EU monitoring body to oversee allergen testing and safety compliance, thereby strengthening health protections without opposing the regulation’s core framework.  

SD emphasizes the necessity of binding timelines for implementing labelling reforms, suggesting Annex II be amended to require biennial progress reports—a minor procedural adjustment to ensure sustained accountability in line with SD’s governance values.

ECR rejects the inclusion of country-of-origin marking requirements as totally disapproveing with their commitment to market efficiency and regulatory simplification.  
ECR opposes the rapporteur's expansion of the proposal's scope, arguing it introduces unnecessary complexities inconsistent with ECR's focus on lean legislation.  
ECR contends that attaching non-core amendments like origin labelling undermines the directive's primary goal of harmonizing textile trade across the EU internal market.  
ECR asserts the issue's diversion into political symbolism overlooks critical industry cost savings and faster product approvals central to ECR's economic priorities.  
ECR totally disapproves with provisions treating textile labelling as a platform for broader protectionist agendas rather than technical standardization.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position by adopting at first reading the proposed legislation based on the Commission’s 2009 proposal (COM(2009)0031), aimed at harmonizing internal market regulations under Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). The resolution emphasized the need to align the proposal with the Treaty of Lisbon’s implications (COM(2009)0665) and incorporated input from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection. It called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements were planned, ensuring procedural continuity. The Parliament instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional cooperation and transparency in the legislative process.

title: Procurement by entities operating in the water, energy, transport and postal services sectors: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on procurement by entities operating in the water, energy, transport and postal services sectors
background: The EU’s existing procurement framework for water, energy, transport, and postal services, governed by sector-specific rules established in the 2000s, faced calls for modernization to address legal ambiguities, market fragmentation, and evolving public service demands. The Parliament will discuss reforms to procurement procedures for entities operating in these sectors, aimed at modernizing rules and streamlining cross-border competition.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses the harmonized procurement framework's emphasis on SME participation through simplified lot division and reduced financial guarantees, aligning with their 2023 competitiveness agenda.  
EPP applauds the shift from "lowest price" to "best value" criteria as a strategic advancement of quality-driven public services, particularly in sectors like school meals and healthcare procurement.  
EPP proposes strengthening implementation monitoring mechanisms to prevent member states from reintroducing bureaucratic barriers during the two-year transposition period.  
EPP endorses the lifecycle cost calculations and innovation incentives as critical tools to meet EU climate targets while maintaining industrial leadership.  
EPP highlights the need for cautious interpretation of social criteria additions to avoid disproportionate administrative burdens on local authorities, while maintaining full support for the directive's core objectives.

EFD slightly advocates the directive but requests revisions to Article 7 to impose strict limits on subcontracting, citing risks of organized crime infiltration through unrestricted supply chains.  
EFD firmly disputes harmonization clauses under TFEU Articles 53/114 as violating subsidiarity principles, aligning with Swedish and UK parliamentary objections to centralized market intervention.  
EFD rejects the cross-border procurement model for failing to protect local SMEs, demanding amended thresholds in Annex II favoring "kilometre zero" businesses and municipal autonomy.  
EFD highlights contradictions in environmental enforcement by allowing non-EU bids that exploit labor conditions, requiring strict origin criteria in Article 19(2)(c) mirroring domestic standards.  
EFD questions enforcement mechanisms, noting Parliament's own procurement failures with the Brussels hemicycle repairs as evidence of systemic bureaucratic inefficiency.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the issue's emphasis on environmental sustainability in public procurement, aligning perfectly with their commitment to leveraging economic tools for ecological transition.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the shift from lowest-cost criteria to life-cycle costing in Article 7, which effectively advances their priority of promoting durable, climate-friendly infrastructure across water and energy sectors.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally promotes the exclusion of water privatization mandates, commending the recognition of citizen-led initiatives like Right2Water as vital to safeguarding public goods.  
GREEN_EFA approves the provisions for contract splitting and reduced bureaucratic barriers, noting this mirrors their manifesto pledges to empower SMEs and local economies through fair procurement practices.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhanced training programs for procurement officers to minimize administrative burdens while maintaining high sustainability standards, ensuring seamless implementation of the directive’s innovative framework.

ALDE absolutely upholds the modernization of procurement procedures as perfectly aligning with their commitment to a competitive single market while preserving municipal autonomy.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue's SME facilitation measures, particularly reduced financial thresholds and lot division, which directly advance their 2023 priority of entrepreneurial growth.  
ALDE absolutely upholds the clarification exempting water services from privatization mandates, effectively advancing their longstanding principle of subsidiarity in critical infrastructure.  
ALDE perfectly supports the integration of social/environmental award criteria as a strategic enhancement to combat wage dumping while maintaining procurement efficiency.  
ALDE absolutely upholds the exemption for non-profit emergency services, strengthening their manifesto pledge to protect civic engagement and volunteer-based models.

SD totally advocates the exclusion of water services from the directive's scope, perfectly aligning with their commitment to safeguarding public control over essential services as demonstrated by supporting the Right2Water citizen initiative.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on social and environmental criteria, endorsing mandatory compliance with collective bargaining agreements and international labor standards for all concession operators and subcontractors.  
SD fully supports the shift from lowest-price to economically advantageous tenders, which enables prioritizing quality, worker protections, and sustainable practices in public procurement processes.  
SD endorses the strengthened legal clarity through distinct rules for concessions and public contracts, ensuring member states' autonomy in organizing services of general economic interest under Treaty principles.  
SD fully approves the SME-friendly measures including contract division into smaller lots and electronic procurement systems, advancing their manifesto goals for equitable market access and reduced bureaucratic barriers.

GUE_NGL conditionally approves the procurement directive's inclusion of social/environmental criteria but requests amendments to Article 3 to mandate minimum quality standards as binding requirements rather than optional considerations.  

GUE_NGL absolutely rejects the concessions directive framework as inconsistent with public service protection principles, demanding explicit exclusion of water management from all liberalization clauses.  

This proposal conflicts with GUE_NGL's anti-privatization stance by enabling market competition in sectors where member states should retain sovereign control over essential services.  

The issue fails to address democratic accountability concerns, requiring deletion of provisions allowing tripartite negotiations without parliamentary amendments (reference paragraph 15c procedural rules).  

GUE_NGL rejects the prioritization of cost-efficiency metrics in Annex II, proposing replacement with mandatory social impact assessments aligned with 2022 Social Progress Protocol benchmarks.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding a Commission proposal (COM(2011)0895) aimed at harmonizing internal market regulations under Articles 53(1), 62, and 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). It highlighted subsidiarity objections from the Swedish Parliament and the UK House of Commons, which argued the proposal exceeded EU competence. The resolution incorporated input from multiple parliamentary committees—Internal Market, International Trade, Employment, Industry, Transport, Regional Development, and Legal Affairs—as well as opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (October 2012). Parliament adopted its first-reading position, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments, and instructed its President to transmit the decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, emphasizing adherence to legislative procedures and subsidiarity principles.

title: Single market governance: REPORT on Single Market governance within the European Semester 2014
background: The European Semester process, established in 2010 under the Europe 2020 strategy, involved annual assessments of member states' economic policies, with the Commission identifying persistent obstacles to Single Market integration in services, energy, transport, and digital sectors through reports from 2011-2013. The Parliament will discuss improving Single Market governance within the European Semester framework.

stances.stance:
EPP fully agrees the integration of Single Market governance as a third European Semester pillar, perfectly aligning with its agenda for structural reforms and competitiveness-driven growth.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the issue's emphasis on accelerating infringement issue through EU Pilot and SOLVIT, mirroring its 2024 Digital Single Market Action Plan priorities.  
EPP fully agrees the call for SME financing enhancements via COSME and Horizon 2020, reflecting its longstanding commitment to entrepreneurship as Europe's growth engine.  
EPP perfectly supports cross-border energy interconnectivity targets, directly advancing its Energy Union strategy for cost-competitive industrial policies.
